fields.description: There is some confusion as to what Eucalyptus implements with regards to the following: * S3 IAM policy * bucket policy * bucket ACLs Can we get some additional information regarding the following: * Which do we support? * Do we have any workflow docs that show how whatever we support is implemented? After the following IAM S3 policy is applied (in this example a group), {code} $ cat s3-all-policy { "Statement": [ { "Sid": "Stmt1361565586161", "Action": "s3:*", "Effect": "Allow", "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*" } ] } {code} The following error is seen: {code} [root@viking-01 s3curl]# ./s3curl.pl --id takecare --get -- -s -v http://192.168.39.102:8773/services/Walrus | xmlindent Unknown option: get * About to connect() to 192.168.39.102 port 8773 (#0) * Trying 192.168.39.102... connected * Connected to 192.168.39.102 (192.168.39.102) port 8773 (#0) > GET /services/Walrus HTTP/1.1 > User-Agent: curl/7.19.7 (x86_64-redhat-linux-gnu) libcurl/7.19.7 NSS/3.13.1.0 zlib/1.2.3 libidn/1.18 libssh2/1.2.2 > Host: 192.168.39.102:8773 > Accept: */* > Date: Sat, 16 Mar 2013 13:53:32 +0000 > Authorization: AWS LLQYBGVCZ4SX4LFBKDAQZ:hCqr6fE77yzYPTV0jK8fXFdBQ5Y= > < HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden < Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8 * no chunk, no close, no size. Assume close to signal end < { [data not shown] * Closing connection #0 403 Forbiddenjavax.security.auth.login.LoginException: Failed to find access key {code} It looks like bucket ACLs need to be applied. Is this the case?
fields.summary: What is the difference between S3 IAM Policy, Bucket Policy and Bucket ACLs?  Which do we support?

comments.body:
*Steps to Reproduce*

* Create a 3.2.0 cloud, and create a couple of accounts, users and groups with EC2 and S3 policies.  Launch some instances, create volumes, create some buckets to make sure everything is working.
* Upgrade 3.2.0 cloud to 3.2.1
* Source creds of eucalyptus/admin user
* Create an account
** euare-accountcreate -a s3policytest
* Create a user under the "s3policytest" account (take note of the access key and secret key)
** euare-usercreate --delegate s3policytest -u lukeskywalker -k
* Create a group under "s3polictytest" account
** euare-groupcreate --delegate s3policytest -g jedis
* Add user "lukeskywalker" to group "jedis"
** euare-groupadduser --delegate s3policytest -u lukeskywalker -g jedis
* Take the attached policy in this ticket, and apply it to the "jedis" group
** euare-groupuploadpolicy --delegate s3policytest -g jedis -f s3-all-policy -p s3-all-policy
* Use s3curl (or any other S3 tool) to see if the user "lukeskywalker" can list buckets on Walrus
** ./s3curl.pl --id lukeskywalker --get -- -s -v http://<Walrus IP>:8773/services/Walrus

If this is confirmed to exist in 3.2.2 testing, this will block 3.2.2. 

[~viglesias], please provide results when you have them.

I performed an upgrade [3.1.2->3.2.2: CentOS-HA + remote sc and remote ws + with equallogic backend] and have looked into this issue.
* Before upgrade the system had several accounts added and a couple users for each account.  Accounts all had policy defined and volumes and snapshots created with every user and instances run with each user (create_resources test) 
* Next, I performed the upgrade.
* After upgrade followed steps to reproduce from [~hspencer] from March 18 and *Did Not* have any issue listing or creating buckets
* Then I added a user that existed before upgrade to this new group with the new policy and still worked
* I went on to create new policies to deny and they worked as expected as well for both pre and post upgrade users.
* I used s3curl as well as cyberduck to connect to Walrus and list, create and delete buckets.

[~hspencer] has indicated that most DB issues arise when components are stopped/started or restarted.  I am going to do another upgrade scenario.  This time I will be restarting components before upgrade and check on this issue again.

when [~hspencer] reproduced a similar symptom as the one in this bug it was due to a completely different code path, namely an issue with the HA databases syncing. In QA we have not been able to reproduce with the steps outlined. 

[~hspencer] [~dstagnaro] can you confirm that the original setup was not HA and thus could not have run into the same issue you did? This does not seem to me like an IAM policy not being honored. Any further info is much appreciated.

[~awithrow], one that we may need to update the Fix Version to 3.3 if it is not going to be addressed in 3.2.2 time frame.

Thoughts?
Darren, sounds like this is no longer a 3.2.2 blocker. I'll remove the Fix version and it will go into the Sust backlog.

After doing some additional research on both Eucalyptus and AWS, I responded back to this [Engage ticket|https://engage.eucalyptus.com/customer/en/portal/questions/908778-eucalyputs-3-2-supports-bucket-sharing-?new=908778] with the following:

=========================================================

Bucket ACLs are supported in the latest version of Eucalyptus (3.2.1). The important thing to note here is that with AWS S3, there are three levels of access controls. They are as follows:

* AWS S3 IAM policy => policy to allow users to execute S3/Walrus actions
* bucket policies => extension to the IAM policy to control access to buckets
* bucket ACLs => ACLs to control which accounts have access to buckets.

More information can be found here:

- http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingAuthAccess.html
- http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingIAMPolicies.html

Eucalyptus supports AWS S3 IAM policies and bucket ACLs. We currently do not support bucket policies. Additionally, any user under the eucalyptus account (i.e. the super admin account), bucket ACLs can't be utilized. This is a bug noted here: 

- https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-5512

Therefore, if bucket ACLs need to be used, any non-eucalyptus account will need to be used. 

For example, to implement bucket ACLs, the following steps can be followed:

1) Source the credentials of the eucalyptus account/admin user.

2) Create two accounts (e.g. accountA and accountB using euare-accountcreate)

3) Create users under each account, creating keys for each user. To keep from downloading the credentials of the admin user of each account, use the --delegate option. (e.g. euare-usercreate --delegate accountA -u foo -k; euare-usercreate --delegate accountB -u bar -k) *NOTE* Make sure and note the access key and secret key that are displayed after each command)

4) Create an AWS S3 IAM policy file to allow users to run S3/Walrus actions. The policy below is an example that you can use:

{code}
{
 "Statement": [
    {
        "Sid": "Stmt1361565586161",
        "Action": "s3:*",
        "Effect": "Allow",
        "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*"
    }
 ]
}
{code}

5) After creating the policy file (lets call it s3-all-policy.txt), upload the policy for each user under each account. (e.g. euare-userupload-policy --delegate accountA -u foo -p s3-all-policy -f s3-all-policy.txt; euare-userupload-policy --delegate accountB -u bar -p s3-all-policy -f s3-all-policy.txt). Now you should be able to use any s3 tool to create, delete buckets and/or objects with easier user. 

6) To allow users from other accounts to access buckets, this is where bucket ACLs come into play. In AWS, when setting bucket ACLs, you use either the Canonical User ID or email address of the account of the user you want to allow access. In Eucalyptus, we use the Account ID. This is a known bug:

- https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-5513

To add a bucket ACL, set up an S3 Tool that supports setting up bucket ACLs. s3cmd (https://github.com/s3tools/s3cmd) is a tool that supports this. To set up an s3cmd config file to use with Eucalyptus, please refer to the following URL under the "Configuration" section. Please ignore the patch section. The latest version of s3cmd works with the latest version of Eucalyptus:

- http://www.eucalyptus.com/eucalyptus-cloud/tools/s3cmd

7) After setting up the configuration file, for example using the access key and secret key of user foo under accountA, use s3cmd to create a bucket - in this example, foobucket. (e.g. ./s3cmd/s3cmd --config=<config file for s3cmd> mb s3://foobucket). 

8) Make note of the account ID of accountB by listing the accounts (e.g. euare-accountlist). In this example, lets say the account ID of accountB is 807363558492. 

9) Use s3cmd to apply the appropriate bucket ACL. A list of the supported bucket ACLs can be found here: 

- http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ACLOverview.html#permissions

In this example, lets apply the read ACL on bucket "foobucket", for any user under the accountB. To do so, run s3cmd using the credentials of user foo under accountA. (e.g. ./s3cmd/s3cmd --config=<config file for s3cmd> setacl --acl-grant read:807363558492 s3://foobucket). You can view the ACL with s3cmd as well (e.g. ./s3cmd/s3cmd --config=<config file for s3cmd> info s3://foobucket)

10) After applying the ACL, create another config file for s3cmd using the credentials of user bar, under accountB. After creating the config file, you should be able to list the bucket "foobucket" using s3cmd. (e.g. e.g. ./s3cmd/s3cmd --config=<config file for s3cmd> la s3://foobucket)

Thats it. You should be good to go. Let us know if you have any issues. Below are some additional links to reference:

- http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ACLOverview.html
- http://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/3.2/cli/eiam.html#eiam

=========================================================

Is this information accurate?  If so, should be add this to our Eucalyptus Admin Guide?

Please let me know if there are any questions.

Cheers,

Harold Spencer, Jr.
Linked because its a request that matches this issue.
I removed the benefit from this issue so that it will hit the bug scrub today.  We can re-set this to High after we review it this afternoon.
[~neil], can you review this ticket and provide info for Harold?
Harold, your info is accurate. We do not support bucket policies, but we do support S3 IAM policies and Bucket/Object ACLs.
Sweet [~neil]. [~awithrow] should we create a DOC ticket off of this, and have it as part of the Admin/User Guide?  Maybe even a new guide (e.g. Eucalyptus Walrus Guide)?

[~smarvin], 

Did this make it into the docs for 3.4.0?  If not, can we get this added to the 3.4.1 docs? [~zhill], is there anything additional needed here regarding S3 IAM policies, bucket policies and bucket ACLs (e.g. are bucket policies supported in 3.4.0?).  Let me know if there are any questions.

There is no change to our IAM support in S3 for 3.4.0. We still do not support bucket policies.

A brief summary of the 3:
1. Bucket ACLs - allow an account to explicity grant access to a bucket or object to another account. ACLs only work between accounts, not IAM users. You specify accounts via CanonicalID or the email address associated with the account (for Eucalyptus this is the email of the account admin).

2. Bucket Policies - are IAM-like policies set by the bucket owner that lets the owner specify access controls for other users or accounts for that specific bucket. Bucket policies look like IAM but the policy is uploaded to S3, not IAM, and the bucket owner sets it rather than the account admin. Bucket policies can allow or deny access to both accounts and IAM users in multiple accounts by the bucket owners. Any ACL can be translated into Bucket Policy, but not the other way around.

3. IAM Policies - set by the admin of an account to control the access of users within that specific account. This is how an admin controls what users in that specific account are allowed to do. Policies can specify allow/deny on specific S3 operations (e.g. s3:GetObject, or s3:PutObject). IAM policies are set by sending the policy to the IAM (Euare) endpoint, not S3 (Walrus).

[~hspencer], we didn't get this in, obviously. But now I'm confused after reading Zach's comment: is there anything to document?

This thread is so long, I'm trying to figure out what the original intent was.

Hey [~smarvin],

[~zhill]'s comments were around that bucket policies still aren't supported in Eucalyptus Walrus.  Currently, there isn't any information in our guides that informs Cloud Admins what we support and what we don't with regards to S3 IAM policies and bucket ACLs.  This is something that - IMO - would go under the section that discusses access control with Eucalyptus Walrus (similar to what [AWS has for S3|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingAuthAccess.html]).  

What specifically to document - I think [~zhill]'s explanation is spot on.

{code}
1. Bucket ACLs - allow an account to explicity grant access to a bucket or object to another account. ACLs only work between accounts, not IAM users. You specify accounts via CanonicalID or the email address associated with the account (for Eucalyptus this is the email of the account admin).
2. Bucket Policies - are IAM-like policies set by the bucket owner that lets the owner specify access controls for other users or accounts for that specific bucket. Bucket policies look like IAM but the policy is uploaded to S3, not IAM, and the bucket owner sets it rather than the account admin. Bucket policies can allow or deny access to both accounts and IAM users in multiple accounts by the bucket owners. Any ACL can be translated into Bucket Policy, but not the other way around.
3. IAM Policies - set by the admin of an account to control the access of users within that specific account. This is how an admin controls what users in that specific account are allowed to do. Policies can specify allow/deny on specific S3 operations (e.g. s3:GetObject, or s3:PutObject). IAM policies are set by sending the policy to the IAM (Euare) endpoint, not S3 (Walrus).
{code}

I think this would be a good high-level summary to help Cloud Admins understand what access controls are available for Eucalyptus Walrus.

I hope this helps.  Please let me know if you have any additional questions.
